newsitem.title: USA: USDA okays transit of Mexican pork from Baja.
newsitem.headline: USDA okays transit of Mexican pork from Baja.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department Tuesday said would allow pork and pork products from the Mexican state of Baja California to transit the U.S. for export to other countries.
USDA said the pork must be packaged in Baja California in a leakproof container and sealed with serial number approved by USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS).
Currently, pork products from Sonora, Chihuahua and Yucatan states are allowed to transit the U.S. for export.

Earlier, as part of President Clinton's state visit to Mexico, the U.S. said it would recognize Sonora state as a low risk area for hog cholera and thereby allow imports of fresh and frozen pork from Sonora to U.S. markets.
